answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
Jason - following up on Gary's comment, you can get to the Managers Who Teach group here: http://bit.ly/yBqX7I
In 2009, NASPAA released recommended "Mission-Specific Elective Competencies: Local Government Management": http://bit.ly/wr36BA
The working group was chaired by Mark Levin and comprised of ICMA members. Their recommendations were:
Graduates of the program will be able to demonstrate the application of their knowledge and understanding of: 
1. The ethics of local government management, emphasizing the role of the professional chief executive. 
2. The roles and relationships among key local and other government 
elected and appointed officials. 
3. The purposes of and processes for communicating with and engaging citizens in local governance.
4. The management of local government core services and functions.
5. The management of local government financial resources.
6. The management of local government human resources.
Scott Lazenby, chair of the Advisory Board on Graduate Education, did his PhD research into this area, and can share some additional ideas.

answers.author: Scott Lazenby
answers.text:
Excerpt from my dissertation: "What the research results do show, however, is that some city management competencies receive a great deal of attention in the public administration academic field, and others are virtually ignored. Most aspects of human resources administration, law and institutions, technical skills such as analysis of policy options, performance measurement, intergovernmental relations, and use of information systems seem to be well-covered. Budgeting is, too, except it is studied mostly from the perspective of the decision-making (policy) process used to arrive at a budget and rarely from the perspective of using the budget in a way that will produce desired behaviors by operating staff (i.e., as a management tool). 
Less well-covered are theories that would support competencies in listening, persuasion, informal communication, understanding the psychological needs of others, project management, empowerment of staff and community members, collaboration, and facilitating participatory decision making."  
For more info, see JPAE, summer 2010, p. 337 - http://naspaa.org/JPAEMessenger/Article/VOL16-3/16no3_final.pdf
Will also attach a summary of 12 major categories and 118 individual competencies that seem important for senior local government managers.

author: Jason Rollins
text: The Alliance is working with Arizona State University (ASU) and other universities to keep the training that MPA students receive most relevant to the field of local government management. What is the most common shortcoming of students emerging from graduate programs in public administration that a university should address?
title: Skills for the Contemporary MPA-holder
